fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Perturbation of the larger chain complex in a chain reduction

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a reduction \rho : C \Rightarrow\mkern{-14mu}\Rightarrow D and a perturbation \delta_C for C, we assume that {h_{\rho}} \mathbin{\circ} \delta_C is pointwise nilpotent, i.e. \forall c \in C_k, \exists n \in \mathbb{N}, \; ({h_{\rho}}\delta_C)^n (c) = 0. We can construct a new chain reduction \rho' : C' \Rightarrow\mkern{-14mu}\Rightarrow D', where C' is C perturbed by \delta_C.
Note that this situation is much harder compared to , as it is generally impossible without the added condition.
For this construction using the third equivalent definition of a chain reduction in , i.e. a homotopy operator on C such that h \mathbin{\circ} h = 0 and h \mathbin{\circ} d_C \mathbin{\circ} h = h.

From the informal discussion above, we can conjecture the formula h' = \sum_{k=0}^\infty (-1)^k (h \delta_C)^k h. This reveals the reason for our pointwise nilpotency condition. With a little bit of care manipulating the infinite sum, we can prove that h' \mathbin{\circ} h' = 0 from h \mathbin{\circ} h = 0, and the second equation follows from a nice telescopic sum \begin{aligned} h' \mathbin{\circ} (d_C + \delta_C) \mathbin{\circ} h' &= \sum_{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} (h \delta_C)^i h (d_C + \delta_C) (h \delta_C)^j h \\ &= \sum_{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} \left[(h \delta_C)^{i + j + 1} h + (h \delta_C)^{i + j} h\right] \\ &= \sum_{k} (k+1) (-1)^k \left[(h \delta_C)^{k + 1} h + (h \delta_C)^k h\right] \\ &= \sum_k (-1)^k (h \delta_C)^k h = h'. \end{aligned}

We can reconstruct the other two components of the reduction {\iota_{\rho'}} and {\pi_{\rho'}} through . In particular, D' is given by a perturbation of D. We only write down the results below for easy reference. \begin{aligned} {\pi_{\rho'}} &= \sum_{k=0}^\infty (-1)^k {\pi_{\rho}} (\delta_C {h_{\rho}})^k \\ {\iota_{\rho'}} &= \sum_{k=0}^\infty (-1)^k ({h_{\rho}} \delta_C)^k {\iota_{\rho}} \\ \delta_D &= \sum_{k=0}^\infty (-1)^k {\pi_{\rho}} \delta_C ({h_{\rho}} \delta_C)^k {\iota_{\rho}}. \end{aligned}

The following data are equivalent.

fr:ul.fr:li: A splitting C \cong D \oplus E, where E is a split exact.
A chain homotopy h : C \to C satisfying h \mathbin{\circ} h = 0 and h \mathbin{\circ} d_C \mathbin{\circ} h = h.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Substituting the requirement that h is a homotopy {\textrm{id}} \to g \mathbin{\circ} f, we get the equation d_{k+1} \mathbin{\circ} r_k + r_{k-1} \mathbin{\circ} d_k = {\textrm{id}}, where d is the boundary operator on E_\bullet. In other words, r is a null-homotopy of E_\bullet, rendering it split exact. Conversely, given C \cong D \oplus E, we can reconstruct f and g as the projection and inclusion maps, with h obtained out of r in the manner depicted above.

Finally, restricting h onto D_k we see that it must be zero, since h({\textrm{id}} - p) = h - h \mathbin{\circ} d \mathbin{\circ} h = 0. This means that all the information of h can be reconstructed from the splitting, and thus all three sets of data are equivalent.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Perturbation of the smaller chain complex in a chain reduction

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a reduction \rho : C \Rightarrow\mkern{-14mu}\Rightarrow D and a perturbation \delta_D for D, we can construct a perturbation \delta_C for C, such that the same \rho can serve as a reduction of the perturbed chain complexes.

Let the reduction \rho be made out of the three maps {\pi_{\rho}} : C \to D, {\iota_{\rho}} : D \to C and {h_{\rho}} : C \to C. Then since C splits as the direct sum of D and an acyclic complex, we can simply copy over the perturbation, and leave the acyclic part untouched. This gives us the definition \delta_C = {\iota_{\rho}} \mathbin{\circ} \delta_D \mathbin{\circ} {\pi_{\rho}}. A quick computation shows that \rho is still a reduction of the perturbed chain complexes.

Given two chain complexes C, D, a chain reduction consists of a chain map \pi : C \to D, a chain map \iota : D \to C and a chain homotopy h : {\textrm{id}} \to g \mathbin{\circ} f, such that \pi \mathbin{\circ} \iota = {\textrm{id}}, and \pi \mathbin{\circ} h = h \mathbin{\circ} \iota = h \mathbin{\circ} h = 0. Here the compositions are understood to have the appropriate subscript so the degrees match.
We write the reduction as \rho : C \Rightarrow\mkern{-14mu}\Rightarrow D. The three components are denoted {\pi_{\rho}} : C \to D, {\iota_{\rho}} : D \to C and {h_{\rho}} : C \to C, respectively.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Chain reduction generated by a discrete vector field

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given an admissible discrete vector field on an algebraic cellular complex (C_k, d), we can generate a chain reduction. It will be computable when the cellular complex is effective.

The DVF partitions the chain groups into a direct sum C_k^{s} \oplus C_k^t \oplus C_k^c, corresponding to source, target and critical cells. We would like to create a reduction to the critical cells only. To do this, we invoke perturbation of the larger chain complex in a chain reduction and start with a simpler chain reduction.

Consider the algebraic cellular complex whose chain groups are C_k, but the differential d'(\sigma) = \pm \tau iff \overrightharpoon{\tau \sigma} is in the vector field, and zero otherwise. The sign is determined as the sign of \tau in d(\sigma). Hence d' : C_{k+1}^{t} \to C_k^s, and is zero otherwise. Therefore using the characterization of chain reduction as a direct sum with a split exact chain complex, we see that this complex can be reduced to the complex on C_k^p whose differential is identically zero.

Next, we try to perturb d' to d. We need {h_{\rho}} \mathbin{\circ} (d' - d) to be locally nilpotent, where \rho is the reduction constructed above. {h_{\rho}} can be viewed as the inverse of d', as it maps the source cell to the target cell. Expanding the definition, we see that this map transports cells down the discrete field line. Since the vector field is admissible, such a transportation eventually terminates and it becomes zero.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This text was written and used for a MAP Summer School at the University of Genova, August 28 to September 2, 2006. Available since then on the web site of the second author, it has been used and referenced by several colleagues working in Commutative Algebra and Algebraic Topology. To make safer such references, it was suggested to place it on the Arxiv repository. It is a relatively detailed exposition of the use of the Basic Perturbation Lemma to make constructive Homological Algebra (standard Homological Algebra is not constructive) and how this technology can be used in Commutative Algebra (Koszul complexes) and Algebraic Topology (effective versions of spectral sequences).
